conversations.content: In the southern plains of Grastaea, there live numerous tribes who worship Zephyr and offer many goods as proof of their devotion.
Such tributes include wooden sculptures, young sheep, horses, and fermented milk—yet a gift of gold is considered to be an ill omen indeed. This is why...
Long ago, a tribe that lived by a river discovered gold dust there and offered it up as tribute. Zephyr immediately took a strong liking to this offering.
＂Bring more of this pretty sand!＂ he ordered, and so the people brought as much as they could find. Satisfied, he then promised the river people his eternal protection.
Zephyr answered their prayers and conjured storms to strike their foes, making the river tribe the undisputed rulers of the region.
Determined to win even more of Zephyr's favor, the tribe began to raid neighboring clans for gold. Soon, they had forgotten all about the fiends they once hunted.
The river tribe had won the blessing and protection of Zephyr. Soon they became outright thieves who stole gold from their neighbors in order to continue currying his favor.
On the day of the summer solstice, a horde of fiends suddenly descended on the river tribe, who desperately implored Zephyr to save them.
Zephyr heard their cries and took to the skies. But the mountain of gold the tribe had collected shone out as bright as the sun itself.
The dragon was confused, for he had never seen the sun descend to earth. But he knew even his dragon's might could not stand against the power of the sun, and so flew away.
When night fell and the gold's glare vanished, Zephyr glided down to the village of the river tribe—only to discover the fiends had slaughtered every last man, woman, and child.
If there is a moral to be learned here, it is that sacrificing one's humility for the protection of a dragon can only lead to destruction.
